body:
I see why a user might *think* we should do that, but it's really not consistent with how environment variables work and I'm not sure if it makes sense to do this.

What if the environment variable is set in the shell config? I have seen plenty of users that would run into problems with that and not understand why it doesn't work.

What if I want the literal, not the expansion?

Generally shell glob expansion is exactly that, a shell thing. Same for environment variables. For script-like configuration files like i3's config this makes sense and in fact I use $HOME in my config. But for a yaml file I'm not so sure. Relative paths should work, so that could help a little bit, but that would be rather messy when starting things from the CLI.

@nixpulvis Would you want this only for paths, or for all environment variables that are strings? Also are you only interested in $HOME or are there other environment variables you might want to use?

I could see just replacing $HOME or ~ maybe. But even stuff like ~undeadleech/alacritty.yml would already make things quite complicated.

I am only currently concerned with expanding the home directory, since I currently have no way to use the `import` config option across multiple users reliably. Otherwise, I'm sure there are interesting use cases that could be imagined with a more general ENV replacement, but I'm fine ignoring them for now.

Also, I wonder how live config reloading would work with ENV variables in general? I think it would be safe to assume `~` will never change it's resolution during the running of alacrity. I haven't tested this in a long time though, so I forget what happens to these values if you change your username.

> Also, I wonder how live config reloading would work with ENV variables in general? I think it would be safe to assume ~ will never change it's resolution during the running of alacrity.

It can't, since the shell changing environment variables won't affect Alacritty.

issue.title: Import config files from home dir or relative
issue.body:
I love the addition of importing config files in 3c3e6870dedad56b270f5b65ea57d5a6e46b1de6
Now i can finally split up OS specific configs easily. 

The issue still is I can't find a way to import from the home directory or relative.
I tried using 

- $HOME
- ~/

Is there something I'm missing or is that feature just not supported yet, since this did whole feature just came to master.

### System

OS: Ubuntu 20.04 / macOS 10.15.6
Version: alacritty 0.6.0-dev (6cfcd7c)
Linux/BSD: X11 + i3 on Ubuntu


Edit:

I found out `.config/alacritty/myfile.yml` is working. So without any prefix it always starts in the home directory. Is that always going to stay like that or should it be possible to make it absolute?

body:
I think it should not work with environment values, because there are to many potential problems there and confusing behaviour to the user.

But there should be a way to reference the home directory. Using `~` would probably be least confusing for users and what most would expect to work.

On macOS the default working directory when starting Alacritty via Spotlight, Finder or just the Dock is `/` so it's hard to have a cross platform path to import a config file.

issue.title: Expand `~` character to home directory in import path
issue.body:
My configuration is managed under source control. It is used on multiple machine and multiple platforms. This means that
I cannot have absolute paths to import files. I format the paths based on my users `~/` directory. This works well on
Linux but on my windows machine it does not understand `~`.

Thoughts on the expansion of `~`:
- If user sets HOME env use that
- If HOME is not set then use `dirs::home_dir()`
  - Windows: `C:\Users\{Username}`
  - Mac: `/Users/{Username}`
  - Linux: `/home/{Username}`

body:
Paths beginning with `~` or `~/` depending on if you want to support the `~undeadleech/alacritty.yml` case should be
expanded to HOME based:

- `HOME` env variable (they might have defined something different then standard)
- Fallback to platforms define defaults: (`dirs::home_dir()`)
  - Linux:   `/home/{username}`
  - Mac:     `/Users/{username}`
  - Windows: `C:\Users\{Username}`

If a user like me that works on multiple machine and multiple platforms (linux, windows), this would allow for one
alacritty config to be in all cases. The documentation for import would explain to user the order of expansion for `~`.

issue.title: Spawn new alacritty process in CWD on macOS

body:
Another solution to @nixpulvis problem would be to support relative paths for the import section. Paths would be relative to the file they are defined in. 

For example, you are using the default configuration location `XDG_CONFIG_HOME/alacritty`. You have broken up your configuration into categories. You directory structure might look something like this:

```
.config/alacritty  tree .
.
|-- alacritty.yml
|-- config
    |-- functional.yml
    |-- input.yml
    |-- theme.yml
    `-- visual.yml
````

In your entry point of your configuration your import section would look something like this:

```yml
imports:
  - config/functional.yml
  - config/input.yml
  - config/theme.yml
  - config/visual.yml
```

As these are relative paths they are relative to the entry file that they were defined in (`~/.config/alacritity/alacritty.yml`) in this example.

@nixpulvis would this help in the mean time while Path/Env expansion is figured out. @chrisduerr your thoughts as well? Also would this be a separate issue?

> @nixpulvis would this help in the mean time while Path/Env expansion is figured out. @chrisduerr your thoughts as well? Also would this be a separate issue?

No it would not. This is just as much work as any other solution and doesn't solve the problem that usernames and host directories might be in different places for different users.
Also relative paths are just a poor idea in general I'd say. It always raises the question relative to what they are. The config file? The working directory? The canonicalized file path?

issue.title: feature: path expansion on config imports
issue.body:
First of all, thank you.  I'm really enjoying alacritty.

My alacritty.yml looks like this:

```yaml
import:
        - /home/matt/.config/alacritty/colors.yml
        - /home/matt/.config/alacritty/config.yml
```

I'd like to be able to use strings like `~/.config/alacrity/config.yml` instead of absolute paths so that when I use git to sync this config to a different machine (with a different username), it all works out.
